docs.title: Welcome to my site!
docs.text:
Warning

This site is still very much under construction. Many, many things are incomplete. Please don't be too judgy. Nobody likes an uninvited critic.

To test if I've set up image handling correctly, here's a picture of an ostrich looking majestic during golden hour: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. docs.title: CV
docs.text: A pdf of my CV can be found here. For other formats or information, please contact me.

docs.title: Astro Photography
docs.text:
Photography

My first attempt of the Andromeda Galaxy - untracked, 24 min exp.

My Second attempt - untracked, <1hr exp.

Orion Nebula - tracked, 11 min exp.

Comet Neowise from Lincoln, July 2020 - untracked, single exp.

docs.text:
Photography

obsidian://open?vault=personal-site&file=docs%2Fassets%2F451738360019.jpg

Reflection of flat building in the river Aire.

A picture of the Royal Armouries Museum tower in Leeds, on top of which I exposed some paper cut outs of flying saucers.

Imaginary friend.

Plant plot - Bank Mills flats on the river Aire.

Camera in place, just rotated 180°. I like the diagonal symmetry.

docs.title: Gallery - Film
docs.text:
See some of my double exposure film photos.

I like the slight glow and retro-futurism of the background. It feels like a still from Jurassic Park, if it were made in the '40s.

Red Kite over Harewood House.

Abbie on the bank of the Thames.

docs.title: Macro Photography
docs.text: Photography

docs.title: Gallery
docs.text:
My first pseudoscorpion! The little devil wouldn't stay still.

A rain spider in the kitchen. In Noordhoek, South Africa.

A jumping spider. Not sure which species, but check out Vida Van Der Walt's website which showcases a multitude of South African jumping spiders. Honestly these are just so cute.

A pair of The common red soldier beetles getting freaky.

A Hawthorn Shield Bug next to an Orange Ladybird larva

My first (successful) photo stack. This is a Fork-Palped Harvestman, sitting on a leaf at Plas Newydd, Wales. See this picture of the fully body for context.

Canestrini's Harvestman on the side of a tree.

An 8-image stack of a woodlouse.

A mite of some sort enjoying a dead fly on a beach in Whitby.

docs.title: Observation wish-list
docs.text:
• More Pseudoscorpions!
  • Heather Crab Spider
  • Ladybird Spider (rare, but are making a comeback)
  • Megabunus diadema - the most punk-looking spider in existence.
  • Zebra Jumping Spider

docs.title: Links
docs.text: NatureFold is an awesome Youtube channel dedicated to macro. I never knew that so many varieties of springtail existed, nor did I expect that anyone could be so knowledgeable and interested in them.

Stags at Chatsworth House.

docs.title: Photography
docs.text: I'm not an avid photographer by any means, but I have dabbled here and there. While I've uploaded a few photos to my Instagram, I also have some a few categorised galleries below.

docs.title: Gear
docs.text:
Camera: Canon 90D DSLR

Lenses: - 75-300mm EF - 18-55mm EF-S - Macro (reverse) mounting adapter ring

Other Bits - Neewer NW645II flash - Simple pop-up flash diffuser

docs.title: Wishlist
docs.text:
• A Tamron 150-600mm - Some zoom so that I'll finally have the reach to get some bird/raptor action shots.
  • A Laowa Macro Lens - As to maintain auto-focus with better zoom and image quality over my current reverse lens solution.

docs.title: Projects - Personal
docs.text: Projects

docs.title: Projects - Professional
docs.text:
Projects

  • Inventor Templates Manager - Inventor, Excel, User-Friendly - Using Excel to define Inventor Templates, and automatically load and reference them to a contract-specific folder.

docs.title: Projects
docs.text: See: - projects-professional - For work and engineering projects. - projects-personal - For anything else that tickles my fancy.

docs.title: Inventor Templates Manager Application
docs.text: Projects - Professional

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Both myself and my colleagues find ourselves designing and adapting a lot of contract-specific CAD arrangements to suit different customer requirements. Each arrangement is an Inventor assembly file which gets added to a larger transformer assembly. To do this efficiently, we have a collection of template parts, assemblies, and drawings located on a shared drive. The necessary files used to be copied over to a contract-specific folder and manually re-linked. This manual process had problems: - The correct files to copy had to be manually located and moved, which took time. - Manually referencing the correct parts to the newly-copied contract-specific assembly was tedious and error-prone; leaving a link to a template part in a contract-specific assembly is not good, and sometimes changes would propagate to completely unrelated contracts.

The aim of this project was two-fold: 1. To allow for templates to be copied over automatically, with all references to parts/subassemblies being updated. In some cases, the time saved is significant - 20mins vs 30s, while removing any chance of human error from the equation. 2. To allow for templates to be added and updated by anyone in the team, with very little configuration or technical knowledge of how the program works.

So I wrote the following desktop program to be used by all members of the Engineering dept.:

I won't go into detail about it's usage, but the general process is as follows: 

---
config:
  theme: redux
---
flowchart TD
    A(["Start"]) --> B["Contract data populated from SQL database"]
    B --> C["Select Template to copy"]
    C --> D@{ label: "Template files are copied and linked as per the 'template definitions' Excel sheet" }
    D --> E(["End"])
    D@{ shape: rect}
The template definitions sheet mentioned above is a shared Excel workbook which simply defines the files, locations, and actions that make up each template:
